user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of response_completed_callback:
```c
static void
response_completed_callback (void *cls,
                             struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             void **req_cls,
                             enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct UploadContext *uc = *req_cls;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == uc)
    return; /* this request wasn't an upload request */
  if (NULL != uc->pp)
  {
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (uc->pp);
    uc->pp = NULL;
  }
  if (-1 != uc->fd)
  {
    (void) close (uc->fd);
    if (NULL != uc->filename)
    {
      fprintf (stderr,
               "Upload of file `%s' failed (incomplete or aborted), removing file.\n",
               uc->filename);
      (void) unlink (uc->filename);
    }
  }
  if (NULL != uc->filename)
    free (uc->filename);
  free (uc);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The three pointer parameters in the function signature are potentially over-writable and should be checked to see whether they could/should be const-qualified: 'cls' and 'connection' are not used (only cast to void) so they could reasonably be declared as pointing to const-qualified types; 'req_cls' is a pointer-to-pointer and its usage should be reviewed to determine whether the pointed-to type could be const-qualified without preventing required modifications via other aliases. Other fragments were not flagged because they involve pointers used to modify the pointed-to objects (so const-qualification would be inappropriate): 'uc' is dereferenced and the UploadContext contents are changed (uc->pp set to NULL, uc->fd closed, uc->filename freed), uc->pp and uc->filename are modified/freed, and the code performs resource-release operations (close, unlink, free) that operate on modifiable objects. The enum parameter 'toe' is not a pointer (passed by value) and thus is not relevant to Rule 8.13.
